fields.LI Template:
Many moons ago as a high-volume recruiter carrying 70+ reqs, I was placed on a PIP for making errors. Despite my best efforts, I was fired.

I remember the heaviness in my heart that day, running 1000 different plays in my head of what I should have done to save my job.

For a long time, I felt like damaged goods.

My confidence was in ruins and I found myself back on my parent's couch at my BIG age (lol) looking for another job.

I lost everything, so I had nothing else to lose.

I decided to apply to jobs outside of NYS.

2 months later I found a new role.

I still carried that old experience into my new job.

I was constantly double and triple-checking my work, afraid to make even the smallest mistake.

I'd spend hours reviewing each candidate's resume, agonizing over every detail.

I'd rehearse conversations with hiring managers endlessly, terrified of saying the wrong thing.

And I'd meticulously document every interaction, fearing that a single misstep could cost me everything again.

(I still do this but NOT to this degree)

But then, a mentor told me something that changed everything: "You are not the sum of that single experience."

This wisdom, along with a few key practices, helped me rebuild my confidence:

1. Setting small, achievable goals and celebrating each win
2. Seeking feedback and focusing on areas of improvement
3. Surrounding myself with supportive colleagues and mentors
4. Continuously learning and upgrading my skills

Despite being fired early in my career, I still got promoted several times throughout my journey, I even landed an Executive role.

Here's what I want YOU to take from this:

The end of a book is the start of a new one.

Now ask yourself this question.

Were you let go by those people at jobs, relationships etc? Or were you FREED?

It's all in the reframe.

#aLITTLEadvice

fields.LI Template:
A little refresher:

WFH does NOT = 2 days in office.

Remote from anywhere does NOT = Live within 10 miles of the office (WFH CAN be within a state of radius based on tax laws)

Hybrid DOES = A combination of days in and out of office

Unlimited PTO = As much PTO as needed within reason and policy, possibly approved by manager in advance.

Unlimited PTO does NOT = You can only take 2 weeks a year

Competitive Salary = Competitive in the industry and job market for similar role. It does NOT = 20 years of experience for entry level pay

A reasonable salary range is NOT 85-300k.

It's not that difficult to be honest, transparent and clear in job descriptions and hiring.

Companies get to choose if they want remote workers, what to pay, and what PTO policies are.

Job candidates get to choose what's most important and what they're willing to accept.

BOTH sides are responsible for clear, transparent communication.

It's not that hard.

Be a good human.

PS:

A year and a half ago I embarked on becoming a career and life coach for working professionals and leaders trying to figure *THIS* all out.  My services are paid, I just don't have the free time to give, but I'm always happy to have an intro call to see if we're a good fit together

And always happy to support workers on LinkedIn

fields.LI Template:
My mother in law rented her house.

For 50 years.

Yes, she paid rent for 50 years.

When the house went up for sale, my husband and I bought it.

He wanted to make sure she was never going to be displaced from the only home she ever knew.

I wanted to make sure she wasn't going to move in with us 😂 😂 😂 .

All joking aside (mostly), we fixed things that needed fixed, replaced the roof, the siding and had a bathroom installed on the first floor.

Any time she needed something, she called.

First, it was things like 'this lightbulb needs changed or the back deck has a loose railing, to I think there are baby bunnies living under the porch.'

My husband, the accountant, is not a handy guy. If I need ANYTHING fixed, I call my Dad or a handyman.

So, when the requests started becoming more and more frequent, I said "Mom, is everything okay?" I know you know how to change a lightbulb.

She'd been widowed, completely independent and self sufficient for all of her adult life.

She told me, 'everything is fine, but when I need something, I know Chris (my husband) or you will come and stay for a visit.'

We were busy.

I was building a business. Raising 2 kids. Running around with their activities, taking care of my own house, cooking, cleaning, etc..all the things moms do.

So what did I do?

Every night when I made dinner, I would make her plate and take it down.

Sometimes I'd stay for 15 minutes, sometimes I'd stay for an hour. I did that for years. And suddenly, the handyman requests stopped.

All she really wanted was our time.

I got a lifetime of stories about my husband (her only child), and the wisdom of a woman who did not have much in the way of worldly posessions, but had so much to give. To share.

She's been gone for years now, but every night when I am packing up the leftovers, I still feel like I should be putting a plate together for her.

Take the time.

Make the time.

Whether it is for your family or a friend or a neighbor. Because in the end, all we have is each other.

And, I scored the top secret family recipes for her famous meatpie.

#resumewriting
#motherinlaw
#familia
#meatpie
#daysarelong

fields.LI Template:
The best way to deliver pricing verbally with your prospects.

Background - All purchasing decisions are emotional. Whether its a scoop of ice cream, a friendship bracelet, or purchasing software, every time humans see a price there is an immediate emotional response.

The Old Way - Deliver the price and then shut up. Whoever speaks first loses.

The Better Way -

1. Deliver the price directly with as few words as possible.
2. Script it out. Yes, write it down.
3. Practice it 5 times before the conversation.

"The price is $_____. How does that feel?"

It is not...

How does that look?

It is not...

How does that sound?

It's about their emotions only. And that is the only thing you want to know.

The best part is nobody can resist answering the question, and their tone will give it away as much as the words they use.

Whatever response you get, you will know exactly where you stand.

fields.LI Template:
$5.2 million 👈

That’s how much my buddy just negotiated for a CRO role at a startup.

Here’s how he did it.

The initial offer was:

- $220k base
- $40k variable (15% of OTE)
- $400k (est.) profit share over next 5 years

The CEO of course thought it was a great offer.

But it wasn’t great, especially for someone with a solid track record coming in to lead all of Sales, CX, and Business Development.

Here was his counter:

- $255k base
- $105k variable (30% of OTE)
- 2x accelerators for hitting plan, AND, most importantly,
- milestone bonuses where for every $10m in ARR the company added in revenue, they’d cut him a check for 1% all the way up to $100m.

Essentially, the milestone plan looked like this:

- $30m arr * 1% = $300k bonus
- $40m arr * 1% = $400k bonus
- $50m arr * 1% = $500k bonus
- $60m arr * 1% = $600k bonus
- $70m arr * 1% = $700k bonus
- $80m arr * 1% = $800k bonus
- $90m arr * 1% = $900k bonus
- $100m arr * 1% = $1m bonus

That’s an additional $5.2 million of bonuses that didn’t exist before.

And remember - that’s ON TOP of cash comp, profit share, and benefits.

Now obviously, this counter was way more than the original offer and there was no way he was gonna get all of it, but the result was pretty fantastic.

In the end, he got:

- $240k base
- $100k bonus + 2x accelerators
- $400k (est.) profit share
- $3.1M milestone plan

That’s $5m potential comp over the next 5 years AND it’s not even close to capturing all the value he added by getting 9 months severance, the ability to advise, and more.

Huge win.

Leaders. You need to learn how to do this.

You need help if you can not yet do it yourself.

So many of you aren’t creative or confident enough with comp plans.

If you want to get smarter about compensation, surround yourself with folks who are passionate about it and love helping others.

Folks like Devon Hennig, who just dropped a kickass playbook for helping directors, VPs and up negotiate senior comp plans and get as much as possible. Folks like Dan Goodman. Heck, maybe even folk like me.

Grab a copy and get smarter about this stuff.

Your bank balance will thank you later.

Check it: CompensationBible.com

fields.LI Template:
At the car dealership this past weekend, a gentleman next to us wanted a firm $34k for his 2024 trade-in vehicle. The dealership came back with $32.5k. The man got up, shook their hand, and thanked them for their time, and WALKED away.

I was impressed, especially as someone who used to settle for the first crumb offer.

$1500.00 less was just that, LESS.

(he was already trading in his six-month-old vehicle for a steal and a deal)

I’m glad he said, “NO. I want the WHOLE POUND CAKE.”

I started thinking about how many of us settled for less in our life/careers.

Wanting to become an executive but → stopping at Sr. Manager instead

Aiming for a leadership role but → settling for team lead

Dreaming of starting a business but → remaining in a comfortable job

(even though both are equally risky)

Aspiring to be an industry expert but → staying as a mid-level specialist

Aspiring to build your personal brand on LinkedIn → but staying silent and scrolling

If only we:

Devised a plan to get to our career goals → Worked the plan

Set ambitious targets → Consistently pursued them

Sought mentorship and guidance → Applied the advice received

Invested in continuous learning → Leveraged new skills for growth

Where would we be?

Living the life we chose?

Or the one we settled for?

Here’s what I want YOU to take from this:

Stop assuming your limits.

Stop fearing the unknown.

Stop undervaluing your worth.

Stop starving yourself for CRUMBS!

Just like the gentleman at the dealership, know your worth and be unafraid to walk away from anything that doesn’t meet it.

And don’t worry about them.

Sure they’ll say you’re difficult.

But you’ll be able to sleep at night knowing you didn’t settle for the Walmart (store brand) GREAT VALUE version of your life.

#aLITTLEadvice

fields.LI Template:
A small invention that changed the construction industry worldwide.

Artur Fischer, a German inventor, is known for having invented the plastic dowel, also known as the "Fischer dowel", in 1958. This small invention revolutionized the construction industry by providing a simple and effective solution for fastening objects to walls made of concrete, brick or other solid materials.

The Fischer anchor consists of a small plastic cylinder with wings on the outside that expand when inserted into a drilled hole in the wall. This creates a firm and secure anchorage for screws, nails or any other type of fixing.

This innovation has changed the DIY and construction industry forever by making it much easier and safer to fix objects to walls. Fischer also has numerous other inventions and patents that underline his role as one of the most important German inventors of the 20th century.

fields.LI Template:
Entrepreneur : “Prospecter ? Déjà essayé : ça marche pas pour moi.”
La réalité : - 100 personnes contactées en 3 mois
- Messages ultra génériques (et mal écrits)
- Zéro gestion des réponses négatives
- Ciblage de très mauvaise qualité
- Aucun suivi des métriques
- Absence totale d’itération.

Ce qu’il aurait fallu faire :

- Identifier 3 à 5 audiences homogènes mais distinctes
- Générer 3 listings de 150 à 200 contacts pour chacune
- Rédiger 3 campagnes-types avec des angles disparates
- Contacter chacun des listings, une campagne-type à la fois
- Analyser méticuleusement les métriques pour identifier les Wins
- Creuser chaque réponse négative pour en comprendre les raisons
- Itérer avec de nouvelles campagnes à la lumière des apprentissages
- Recommencer en augmentant les volumes à chaque nouvelle itération.

De toutes les boîtes qu’on a accompagnées, je n’en ai croisé aucune pour qui la prospection n’était pas adaptée.

Dans l’immense majorité des cas, l’échec était dû à :

- Un manque de travail
- Un manque de méthode
- Un manque de patience.

La question n’est pas : “est-ce que la prospection est faite pour moi ?”

La seule question qui vaille, c’est : “comment la faire fonctionner pour ma boîte ?”

Write this down:

Stop asking for permission to add value, and just add value.

There is a huge difference between offering value, and giving value.

Providing value upfront is way better than convincing someone that you have something valuable to share.

Don't ask someone who's adrift at sea if they want a life raft, just toss it to 'em.

Don't ask me if I'd like an intro to a potential client, just surprise me and do it.

I promise you I'll be far more interested in learning more afterwards.

Most salespeople are self-serving.

The irony is they end up serving no one.

Including themselves.

The Old Way:

- Do they fit MY qualification criteria?
- Do they have the budget to pay ME?
- Do they already work with MY competition?

The New Way:

- Do THEY need to act?
- Do THEY need outside help?
- Do we have the best solution for THEM?

Stop trying to sell your stuff, and start helping people buy things that will solve their problems.

fields.LI Template:
3 years ago, I was helping close a $385,000 deal.

It was a ‘make or break’ deal for quarter-end.

But of course: Procurement was grinding us down on price.

THEM: "$385k is INSANE. We only have budget for $200k."


We had to bring the focus off price and back to value.

Here's what we said next:



US: "How familiar are you with the business value we're poised to deliver?"

THEM: "I'm familiar. You're going to help us ramp new sellers faster. That's valuable. But not worth $385,000."

Dead end? Nope.

Then we took it to the next level:


US: "Can we walk you through the math we did with your CRO to see if it checks out?"

THEM: "Sure."

US: "Your AE ramp time is 8 months. At month 9, the avg. rep starts producing $60k in ARR/month after 7 months of ramping up. That sound right?"

THEM: "Yep."

We were getting closer:


US: "Your CRO tells us she's hiring 80 new AEs in the next 12 months."

THEM: "Mmhmm."

US: "So if you got 80 new AEs up to speed one month faster each: That's 80 * $60k in ARR = $4.8M."

THEM: *sitting silent*

Then we asked these questions:


US (again): "The question then becomes, how believable is it that we can cut a month off your ramp time?"

THEM *now the CRO chimes in*: "Very believable. I'm gone deep with them on this."

US: "So $4.8M expected return against a $385k spend."

Now for the nail in the coffin:

US: "Usually when we get price resistance, it's either because:

1) you're not sold on the financial value

2) you do not have the ability to spend the cash.

It feels like we covered #1.

What's stopping us from here?"

They signed 6 hours later.


Here are 3 deal-closing lessons from this deal:


1. Get your champion in the negotiation room.

Procurement rarely 'gets' the business value.

Get your champion in the room when it's time to face off with them.

Yes, you won't always be able to.

But shoot your shot and at least ask.

It will change the tone of the meeting.


2. Price resistance comes from 1 of 3 places:

A) Not sold on the value

B) Inability to pay

C) Just trying to get a better deal.

Identify which one you're up against. Then navigate accordingly.

For us, it was a combination of 1 & 3.



3. Negotiating is MUCH easier with rock-solid selling skills.

We had a few things going for us:

- a committed champion
- significant business pain
- quantifiable business value

Imagine negotiating without those?

Would have been a nightmare.

That’s all for today. If this either:

A) Taught you something

B) Inspired you

Drop a 💯 in the comments.

P.S. Tired of inconsistent, unpredictable quota attainment?

Here's a repeatable 5-step SaaS selling system:
- uncover business pain that money follows
- generate white hot urgency from thin air
- sell in an economic meltdown

fields.LI Template:
Company culture is just as important as the bottom line, if you have a toxic culture you'll lose...

People are the driving force behind your business, and creating a positive and empowering culture is essential for the success of your business.

That means you have to understand what your employees want at a deep level. You have to be constantly adapting to their needs and what they want from the organization.

For example, one of my employees might want higher pay when he’s 24. But maybe he falls in love at 28 and decides he wants to spend more time with his family. Another might be more interested in a fancy title. Another might want to get access to me and build a relationship.

Another might want to go to one of our international offices and work there.

There are a million different variables, and it’s on you as a leader to adjust to reality as it changes.

Culture is not something you can just hang on a wall and call it a day.

A strong culture is built through consistent actions and decision-making.

Either you care about your culture because you actually understand it...

or you just say it because it looks 'good' and you actually don't care and you just care about your short term money.

Don't underestimate the power of investing in your employees.

It's not just the right thing to do, it's also a smart business move.

Here are seven strategies to recharge and fight back, shared by Colby Kultgen.

𝟭. 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘇𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝟳 𝗧𝘆𝗽𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘁
*Physical: Prioritize sleep and relaxation.
*Mental: Incorporate meditation into your routine.
*Social: Spend time with uplifting people.
*Spiritual: Volunteer or engage in meaningful activities.
*Sensory: Take breaks from screens and noise.
*Emotional: Talk to a trusted friend or counselor.
*Creative: Enjoy hobbies like reading or music.

𝟮. 𝗗𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗧𝗲𝗰𝗵-𝗙𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗭𝗼𝗻𝗲𝘀

𝟯. 𝗘𝗺𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗲 𝗦𝗮𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 "𝗡𝗼"
*Set boundaries to protect your time and energy.
*Freedom comes from being able to say "no" when necessary.

𝟰. 𝗣𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝗡𝗮𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗽𝘆

𝟱. 𝗔𝘃𝗼𝗶𝗱 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗘𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝗗𝗮𝘆

10 hours before bed: No caffeine.
3 hours before bed: No food.
2 hours before bed: No work.
1 hour before bed: No screens.

Over 90% of people lack critical thinking skills.

They're becoming more rare and valuable every day.

But what exactly is critical thinking?

In simple terms, it means:

— Closely analyzing information to form a judgment
— Questioning what you see, hear, and read
— Not just accepting things at face value

Why is this important?

Because it helps you:

— Make better decisions
— Solve problems more effectively
— Avoid being misled by false information

In a world full of noise and distractions,
critical thinking helps you cut through the clutter.

How can you improve your critical thinking?

➟ Start by asking the right questions.

It takes practice. But it pays off in every aspect of life.

So, the next time you encounter information,
don't just accept it.

Question it. Analyze it. Think critically about it.

The quality of your thinking determines
the quality of your life.

fields.LI Template:
“What do you do with a top performer who doesn’t follow best practices?”

I got this question in a recent AMA in the Sales Leadership Accelerator monthly group calls.

My the answer had 2 parts.

The first part.

“If they are your best, MAYBE that’s actually what the best practice looks like.

Your job as the leader is to diagnose what it is they are doing better and different than everyone else and see if you can codify it.

To often we try to make the top conform to the rest vs the rest conform to the top.

Which one will pay off better?”

Part 2

“You also need to truly determine what a non negotiable is for your org.

Non negotiable means just that. Non negotiable.

So if that’s CRM hygiene then you have to hold the line.

Sell the rep on why they need to, how it will benefit them in the short term and long term, and also see if there are ways to make it easier.

If they are a true top performer, and they just suck at all the admin, for the love of god get them a VA.

But if you’re not willing to fire them over it, pick your battles and move on.

But if it’s cultural, if they are brining people down. If they are lacking integrity.

That is a non negotiable in my book and I have gotten rid of a top perform like that and watched TEAM performance improve”

—

This is why I love the group calls because we can go far deeper on topics and get inputs from others as well.

The TLDR here is

Study Greatness. Codify it and scale it.

Hold the line on non negotiables. Pick your battles.

We are up to over 50 leaders in the Sales Leadership Accelerator and it’s growing each and every day.

Get in there.

You might just like it.

fields.LI Template:
9 Essential Components of a Production Microservice Application

1 - API Gateway
The gateway provides a unified entry point for client applications. It handles routing, filtering, and load balancing.

2 - Service Registry
The service registry contains the details of all the services. The gateway discovers the service using the registry. For example, Consul, Eureka, Zookeeper, etc.

3 - Service Layer
Each microservices serves a specific business function and can run on multiple instances. These services can be built using frameworks like Spring Boot, NestJS, etc.

4 - Authorization Server
Used to secure the microservices and manage identity and access control. Tools like Keycloak, Azure AD, and Okta can help over here.

5 - Data Storage
Databases like PostgreSQL and MySQL can store application data generated by the services.

6 - Distributed Caching
Caching is a great approach for boosting the application performance. Options include caching solutions like Redis, Couchbase, Memcached, etc.

7 - Async Microservices Communication
Use platforms such as Kafka and RabbitMQ to support async communication between microservices.

8 - Metrics Visualization
Microservices can be configured to publish metrics to Prometheus and tools like Grafana can help visualize the metrics.

9 - Log Aggregation and Visualization
Logs generated by the services are aggregated using Logstash, stored in Elasticsearch, and visualized with Kibana.

Over to you: What else would you add to your production microservice architecture?

–

fields.LI Template:
I meet with 100s of executives and aspiring founders every year.

They often ask for advice on how to build something in the AI industry.

Here's what I tell them:

1/ Identify the Real Problem:
AI is a powerful tool, but it's not a solution in search of a problem.
Don't get attracted by the latest advancements.
Instead, focus on a specific industry or challenge you're passionate about. What deep-rooted inefficiencies are begging for disruption?

2/ Become a Domain Expert First:
You don't need a PhD in machine learning to win in AI.
Far more valuable is a deep understanding of your target market and the data landscape.
Become the expert who can bridge the gap between real-world needs and the potential of AI solutions.

3/ Start Small, Win Fast, Learn Faster
Don't get bogged down building a world-changing AI platform on day one.
Begin with a focused, achievable project that delivers a clear value proposition.
This agile approach allows you to validate your concept, gather data, and iterate quickly – all crucial for long-term success.

4/ Ethics First, Always
AI is powerful, but with great power comes great responsibility.
Bake ethical considerations into your foundation from the very beginning.

Consider potential biases, ensure data privacy, and prioritize transparency in your AI development.

What advice would you give to someone building something in AI? Share in the comments!

#aitool #entrepreneurship #founder

This is one of my favorite movie scenes of all time...

It always hits me hard:

"No I didn't rush the f*cking field, I wasn't there...I was in a bar having a drink with my future wife.

That's why I'm not talking right now about some girl I saw at a bar 20 years ago. How I always regretted not going over and talking to her.

I don't regret the 18 years I was married to Nancy, I don't regret the 6 years I had to give up counseling when she got sick, and I don't regret the last years when she got really sick.

This is a harsh reality of life:

You always romanticize the ROAD NOT TAKEN.

The antidote is to spend more time appreciating the beauty of the road you did take.

Lack of appreciation is where your happiness goes to die.

fields.LI Template:
My favorite pizza place takes their phone off the hook when they are busy.

They have no website.

You cannot order their pizza from an App.

They don't Door Dash.

You cannot text or email your order.

When they do answer the phone, they have NO technology that identifies your number and provides your delivery address.

I've been going there for 30+ years, and EVERY SINGLE TIME I have to give my name and my address.

But it is the BEST pizza I've had, and I've had a lot of pizza 😀.

A few weeks ago, I stopped by to do a pick up.

It was at least 95 degrees outside.  They have no AC.

They run a few fans, but I would say that it had to be at least 110 degrees in there with 4 pizza ovens running at full tilt.

But everyone was joking around.

Classic rock and roll playing in the background.

A driver was waiting patiently for his pizzas for delivery.

It's been the same crew, same people...

It's been the same owner, always there....toiling away and making pizzas with his kitchen staff.

The product speaks for itself and there were at least 10 people picking up pizzas as the same time as me.

When businesses try too hard to convince you that something is the best, they are probably trying too hard.

True excellence doesn't need to be shouted from the rooftops or plastered all over social media.

It shines through in the product, in the dedication of the people behind it, and in the loyalty of the customers who keep coming back.

Keep that in mind when you are looking for a job....sometimes, the best places to work are just quietly busy, being the best places to work.

#resumewriting
#jobsearch
#pizzaplace
#best
#tryingtoohard

fields.LI Template:
The worst salespeople look to the buyer for next steps.

They don't take a leadership position.

They don't know what to do next.

They hope the buyer does.

Their deals stall and die.



GOOD salespeople *recommend* next steps.

They know that selling is an act of leadership.

They're "seen this movie before," having closed several deals.

Their buyer, hasn't.

This is their first time buying.

So good sellers recommend next steps:

- WHAT should we next?
- WHO should be involved?
- WHY is this is best step?

They can answer all three of those.



The BEST salespeople do both of the above.

They take a leadership position.

They always have a point of view on next steps.

But.

They don't steamroll their buyers with it.

They collaborate:

"I have a point of view on where we should go from here.

"But you know your company better than me.

"Before I share my thoughts, what do you think we do next?"

Sometimes, the buyer has a better next step than the seller.

Great sellers take that.

But most of the time?

The buyer doesn't want to think.

That's your job.

They want to hear from you.

Like I said.

Selling is an act of leadership.

That means two things:



First, you know the way.

You have a point of view.

You're not shy about recommending it.



Second, you don't steamroll people with it.

You want to hear from them.

You collaborate rather than command.

Strike that balance?

You're that much closer to becoming a President's Club contender.

Why is the credit card called “𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐦𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 product in banks”? How does VISA/Mastercard make money?

The diagram below shows the economics of the credit card payment flow.

1. The cardholder pays a merchant $100 to buy a product.

2. The merchant benefits from the use of the credit card with higher sales volume, and needs to compensate the issuer and the card network for providing the payment service. The acquiring bank sets a fee with the merchant, called the “𝐦𝐞𝐫𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐝𝐢𝐬𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭 𝐟𝐞𝐞.”

3 - 4. The acquiring bank keeps $0.25 as the 𝐚𝐜𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐤𝐮𝐩, and $1.75 is paid to the issuing bank as the 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞 𝐟𝐞𝐞. The merchant discount fee should cover the interchange fee.

The interchange fee is set by the card network because it is less efficient for each issuing bank to negotiate fees with each merchant.

5. The card network sets up the 𝐧𝐞𝐭𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐬 with each bank, which pays the card network for its services every month. For example, VISA charges a 0.11% assessment, plus a $0.0195 usage fee, for every swipe.

6. The cardholder pays the issuing bank for its services.

Why should the issuing bank be compensated?
🔹The issuer pays the merchant even if the cardholder fails to pay the issuer.
🔹The issuer pays the merchant before the cardholder pays the issuer.
🔹The issuer has other operating costs, including managing customer accounts, providing statements, fraud detection, risk management, clearing & settlement, etc.

Over to you: Does the card network charge the same interchange fee for big merchants as for small merchants?

–

fields.LI Template:
3 outbound plays that convert at 40%.

(Save this post for later)

Alley Oop

Y'all remember the iconic D Wade to LeBron oop?

That's exactly what this play is.

On LinkedIn, you can CC someone in a message.

Here's what you do:

• The SDR (Sales Development Representative) reaches out to the prospect.
• Tags the Account Executive (AE) in the message as well.
• The AE joins the conversation, even if they're not connected.
• Have the SDR reach out first and have the AE follow up.

This works wonders as a pattern interrupt.

2. Surprise Step Back

From LeBron James to the James Harden step back.

Not what you were expecting in this post but stay with me.

This is a play we execute when someone has viewed our profile.

When someone views our profile, it means they are interested.

If someone views your profile, you ask this:

"Sally - saw you viewed my profile. How can I help?" or "Did I do something wrong?"

This starts a conversation in the DM's almost every single time.

If they are a second or third-degree connection and fit your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP), connect with them.

3. The Inspector Gadget.

When someone follows your company.

It's time to do more investigation.

Send them an email or connection request with this framework.

Reason:
“Noticed you follow our company page.”

Value:
“We have been working with other clients in your Industry to achieve x, y, and z.”

CTA:
“Would you be open to a deeper dialogue?”

A great connection request would go like this:

"Noticed you follow our company page. What content sparked your interest?"

This is one of my favorite plays to execute.

P.S. Which play stood out to you?

fields.LI Template:
I work for my employees. They don’t work for me.

Some people may think this is counterintuitive to being a “boss” but I actually believe that this is an incredibly important part of being a boss.

The owner of a business is entirely responsible for everything that happens under that umbrella, including the employees.

If you don’t like how something is happening within your company or how employees are performing, it’s your processes or frameworks that created those issues in the first place.

Everyday I think about how I can put players in a position to succeed – that means delivering feedback with radical candor in a constructive way, observing everyone’s strengths and weaknesses, and understanding what everyone cares about at any given time.

If you’re fortunate enough to be a “boss” or “manager”, be a leader... build people up instead of tearing them down!

fields.LI Template:
Asking for $20k more on a $200k+ job offer is a 🚩

Most executives - especially greener ones - are obsessed with cash.

They’re worried: “Ugh, they offered 200 but I want 220. What should I do?”

Who gives a crap?

$20k more a year is less than $500 per paycheck after taxes.

At the senior level, you shouldn’t give a shit about $500 per paycheck.

What you SHOULD care about is setting yourself up for larger lump-sum opportunities and protecting yourself in case something bad happens.

That means asking for things like:

- Milestone bonuses
- Clawback protection
- Funding participation
- 6-12 months severance
- Aggressive accelerators
- Double triggers on equity
- Cashless | Extended Exercising
- Headcount for senior leadership like SalesOps
- Ability to consult and advise without catching flack

The problem is no one teaches you how to negotiate this stuff.

You waste years getting burned, and you leave a lot on the table before you figure it out.

I know I did. Which is one reason I'm super passionate about this stuff and remain involved in projects to help.

If you want to skip the pain and suffering, surround yourself with folks who have done it before and are passionate about helping others.

Folks like Devon Hennig , who just dropped a kickass playbook for helping directors, VPs and up negotiate senior comp plans and get as much as possible.

We’ll have him on the Surf and Sales podcast soon, but grab the guide in the meantime.

100% worth it.

Check it: CompensationBible.com

fields.LI Template:
Collaboration is the heartbeat of innovation! Here's how to kick-start effective teamwork:

🤝 Open Communication: Begin with clear communication. Define goals, roles, and expectations upfront.


📊 Common Purpose: Align on the project's purpose. Shared understanding fuels collective effort.


👥 Diverse Perspectives: Embrace diverse viewpoints. Different insights enrich problem-solving.


👂 Active Listening: Hear each other out. Actively listen to ideas before offering your own.


🙌 Mutual Respect: Treat everyone's input with respect. Each person brings unique value.


📅 Set Deadlines: Establish timelines for tasks. Accountability keeps the collaboration on track.


🧠 Brainstorm Freely: Encourage brainstorming without judgment. Unleash creativity without restrictions.


🤔 Constructive Feedback: Provide feedback respectfully. Constructive critique enhances outcomes.


🚀 Leverage Strengths: Assign tasks based on strengths. Leveraging skills boosts efficiency.


💡 Shared Tools: Use collaboration tools. Technology streamlines communication and document sharing.


🙋‍♀️ Assigned Roles: Designate a lead or facilitator. Clear roles prevent confusion.


🔀 Adaptability: Be flexible as plans evolve. Adaptation fosters agile collaboration.


🗣 Regular Updates: Maintain ongoing updates. Transparency minimizes surprises.


💬 Team Huddles: Schedule regular check-ins. Quick meetings keep everyone on the same page.


🙏 Appreciation: Acknowledge contributions. Celebrate wins and show gratitude.


📚 Continuous Learning: Reflect on what worked and what didn't. Continuous improvement enhances future collaboration.


Ready to dive into successful teamwork?

Remember, collaboration thrives on synergy and shared goals.

How do you kick-start effective collaboration?

Stop slowly building up in the week.

Mondays need to be HOT!

How you start your week and end your week are crucial.

Monday should start with massive action towards your goal.

Big activity day. Calls. Videos. Emails. Etc

Not a team meeting at 9/10.

LEADERS:  I try to avoid having ANY morning meetings for my teams, it disrupts the flow significantly.

Not starting to figure out your week.

Monday am should come in HOT.

Friday afternoon is for the planning and prep.

End the week with a good 60 min to review, recap, and plan your NEXT week.

Get that Monday am call list ready.

Get your calendar blocked out. Remove things that aren't necessary.

End the weeks with at least the plan on how to make Monday epic.

Start fast.

End smart.

That’s the key.

Over the past 15 years, I've DONATED $300,000 to my employers.

(I know, highly unusual but also very common)

By leaving money on the table!

How?
- Not negotiating my salary during the hiring process
- Leveraging dated information from unreliable websites
- Sharing my current salary as the starting point for my new salary

Yes, if you play stupid games you will win stupid prizes.

The prize in my case was becoming a steal and a deal.

And in many cases being the lowest paid team member.

Resulting in:
- Finding out coworkers made $10,000 more than me
- Discovering colleagues earned $30,000 more
- Learning peers were making $50,000 more

Being told "way to go" and "good job" does not cash at the bank.

This experience taught me that no one will ever look out for you more than you. If tools like FairComp were around during this time, I would have leveraged up-to-date salary information to negotiate internally and externally.

It's a far more effective strategy than seeing your peer-level co-workers paystubs on accident at the company printer.

FairComp is a free platform that provides salary, equity, and bonus data to help users assess fair pay, while sourcing verified data and aiming to obtain more granular company-specific insights through user contributions.

Remember, donations are for real charities in need, your financial potential with your employer is NOT one of them.

fields.LI Template:
My biggest sales lesson I learned from John Barrows.

Give a Shi*t.

Grab your coffee because it's story time.

Anyways, John and I were chatting in our weekly 1x1.

He asked me, "How are you feeling about everything?"

• Expressed I felt grateful for the opportunity
• Elaborated on how I was learning a ton about sales
• Explained how I felt lost because I was doing the right sales motions, but wasn't seeing much success

He paused for a minute and said.

"It's because you don't Give a Shi*t."

I got defensive and said: "Whatchu talkin' bout, Willis?"

He came back and said this:

"It's not that I don't think you don't care. You are a good kid. What I mean is you are going through the motions, and you truly don't care about customers enough to help solve their problems. They sense that, and that is why you are stuck."

That conversation hit home with me.

After that call, I got to work.

• Started doing informational calls with enablement leaders on how they wanted sales training run
• Binged all the sales podcasts that had sales leaders on them
• Studied my industry inside and out

My results changed when I decided to make a change.

So if you ever struggle, ask yourself...

Do you Give a Shi*t?

10 Key Data Structures We Use Every Day
.
.
- list: keep your Twitter feeds
- stack: support undo/redo of the word editor
- queue: keep printer jobs, or send user actions in-game
- hash table: cashing systems
- Array: math operations
- heap: task scheduling
- tree: keep the HTML document, or for AI decision
- suffix tree: for searching string in a document
- graph: for tracking friendship, or path finding
- r-tree: for finding the nearest neighbor
- vertex buffer: for sending data to GPU for rendering

Over to you: Which additional data structures have we overlooked?

fields.LI Template:
You 𝐝𝐨𝐧'𝐭 have to be an expert to build a personal brand, but you 𝐝𝐨 need to be an expert to be a thought leader.
.
.
For me, #personalbranding has never been about your LinkedIn profile and content, its always been much deeper than that.
.
My experience with personal branding started in 2000, and since then, I have created software that can dig deep into a person's soul to find their true self.
.
But for a long time, I have struggled with where personal branding is going because 99% of the people I work with are not interested in becoming famous.
.
They are interested in sharing their genius and creating impact.
.
I have worked with some of the best talent in the world, including high-level government officials, neuroscientists, heads of academic business schools, highly credentialed special forces soldiers, lawyers, and musicians.
.
All of these people are specialised. They have no interest in fame or going viral.
.
I realised that personal branding is diluted because it is so strongly aligned with "influencers," and this is dying in a big way.
.
I was watching an interview with the owner of the biggest influencer marketing agency, and he said, "80% of influencers do not and cannot influence."
.
He even said that big brands are now looking for specialists who have an engaged real community and a much smaller following.
.
This is why, for me, thought leadership is the future.
.
Thought leadership is not about how many followers I have or whether my post will go viral—it's about sharing what I know and my wisdom.
.
It takes away all the do's and don'ts of how to be famous because thought leaders are not chasing that.
.
Instead, it attracts the right connections, clients and partners.

Global sales expansion has never been easier.

It's still hard, but Zoom made it easier.

You still have to navigate:
-time zones
-languages
-cultural buying styles
-different integrations

It's arguably easier to sell into the US from overseas than vice versa now.

But it didn't used to be this way.

Still trying to determine all that it means.

But it certainly indicates a global shift away from US dominance.

I don't see this as a US decline, but a rise in overseas quality and execution.

EMEA and APAC are essentially now in the same ballpark as US SaaS.

With all that's changing in the world, I feel this has somewhat gone unrecognized.

It wasn't long ago that it was perceived as a negative if a SaaS company wasn't based in the US.

I never hear this mentioned from customers or employees anymore.

It's all the same now, and it deserves a shout out.

Well done 👏

fields.LI Template:
Micro-managing should NEVER be your first action to someone in your team struggling 👇

The first thing you should do is TALK to them

Ask them what they think went wrong
Ask them if anything else is going on in their lives
Ask them what they need

Too many managers go straight to a PIP or to micro-managing, often pushing out talented employees who just needed a bit of support

Micro-managing is the easy option
But it's rarely the right option

Try these 3 things instead:

1 - Have a supportive private 1-2-1 with them, make them feel at ease and feel supported by you and the company

2 - Work with them to identify what might have gone wrong or challenged them last month and come up with solutions together

3 - Ensure you provide them with all of the support and resources that you can to help them succeed

Everyone has a bad month
Many have a few bad months
Even managers have bad months

Most people will respond a lot better to being supported than to being micro-managed

Do you agree?

fields.LI Template:
If you’re a CEO you SHOULDN’T expect your employees to be working as much as you.

Period.



The CEO at a former company I worked at, used to tell me he was frustrated no one worked as hard as him.

He complained that he worked every weekend (and he sent us all emails all weekend too).

He worked late at night (and called often when I was at 8pm baseball games, in mom mode).

He talked about how he started work at 5am every day (and often made his leaders get on calls at 6:30am).

He couldn’t understand why “these younger generations” didn’t have the same work ethic.

What he failed to realize is “younger people” aren’t lazy.

They aren’t less dedicated.

They aren’t different than any generation before them.

They simply know what’s important to them, as every generation does.

He is the leader of the company and likely makes far more money than anyone else.

You can’t expect someone in an entry level role to have the same responsibilities and work hours as someone making 350k+.

We all should take personal pride in our work

We should give it our best, whatever that is day to day.

We should work hard, there’s no substitution for it

But how you choose to work as an executive should NOT be how you expect your team to work.

Hustle away, just don’t create hustle culture for others.

Be a good human. Lead well.

PS: If you're looking to work with a paid coach who has failed Yoga and Meditation, but knows the importance of harmony in career and life... please reach out if you’d like to work together

Happy to support good humans on their journey.

fields.LI Template:
From Snowdrifts to Snowflake: How One Cloud Solution is Avalanching the Data Engineering Landscape

As data engineers, we've all felt buried under the ever-growing snowdrifts of data.

What once fit comfortably in traditional databases now floods our systems daily. This data deluge presents both challenges and opportunities for businesses across all sectors.

Enter Snowflake: a game-changer in the world of data warehousing.

1. Cloud-Native Architecture: Snowflake's design separates storage and compute, allowing for unprecedented scalability. Need more processing power for a big query? Scale up instantly without touching your storage.

2. Multi-Cloud Flexibility: One of Snowflake's standout features is its ability to integrate seamlessly with major cloud providers. Whether your infrastructure is on AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud, Snowflake has you covered. This flexibility is crucial for businesses with multi-cloud strategies or those considering cloud migration.

3. Snowpipe for Real-Time Data: Gone are the days of complex ETL schedules. With Snowpipe, data flows into your warehouse in near real-time. Imagine the possibilities for real-time analytics and decision-making!

4. Snowpark: The In-Database Processor: If Snowpipe is the courier, Snowpark is the on-site data scientist and engineer rolled into one. It allows you to process and transform data right where it lands.

5. Time Travel and Data Recovery: Ever accidentally dropped a crucial table right before a big presentation? Snowflake's Time Travel feature lets you query data as it existed at any point in the past 90 days. It's like having a time machine for your data.

6. Secure Data Sharing: Share live, governed data across organizations without moving or copying it. This feature opens up new possibilities for data monetization and collaboration.

7. Support for Diverse Data Types: From structured tables to semi-structured JSON, Snowflake handles it all. This versatility is invaluable in today's varied data landscape.

This multi-cloud approach means you're not locked into a single provider. You can choose the best cloud services for each aspect of your data pipeline while using Snowflake as your central data warehouse.

fields.LI Template:
14 years ago I had $40 to my name. My dream was to become a pro drummer.

After practicing 6 hours a day for years, I got tendinitis in both elbows and permanent scar tissue.

A "career-ending injury," in drummer-speak.

Had no idea what to do next.

My girlfriend at the time (now my wife) bought me dinner most nights.

I couldn't afford more than Top Ramen (and she had a job).

Then one day (after my car battery died and I couldn't afford a new one) I made a vow:

I was going to become a millionaire by age 30.

I was DONE with living a life of financial scarcity.

I saw that rip apart my parent's marriage, and I was committed to leaving that in my past.

Didn't know how I was going to do it. But didn't care.

I just needed a new "life dream" to shoot for.

When I told my roommate (now my co-founder) about my new goal, he said something that changed my life:

"If you want to do well for yourself economically, spend your time getting really, really good at selling."

Those words etched a bike path on my brain.

I took them to heart (and I still do).

I went to Barnes and Noble.

Bought a book called "How I Raised Myself From Failure to Success In Selling."

Tore through it in three days. Mind-spinning with possibility.

And soon became obsessed with mastering this thing called "Sales."

Fast forward, and a few things happened.

I went from:
- selling door to door coupon books, to
- selling home security over the phone, to
- becoming an SDR at a local tech company, to
- becoming an AE then RSM at that company, to
- starting my first ( real) company (and failing), to
- helping grow Gong from $200k to $200M, to
- making my first $1,000,000 before age 30, to
- growing pclub to multi-7 figure ARR in 1 year
- read 500 books on business in a decade

What's the point of me sharing this?

Simple:

Focus on relentless skill acquisition, and your dream life follows.

Everyone thinks it takes several decades to achieve huge things.

And sure, a long-term focus is important.

But the REAL distance between where you are now and where you want to be is not measured in time.

It's measured in skills.

Your dream life demands that you acquire certain skills.

Acquire those skills faster, and you compress the time it takes to reach your goal.

Tony Robbins has a story he tells often:

He 'mastered' public speaking in a year where it takes others decades.

How?

At the beginning of his career, instead of speaking once a week, he'd speak 3x a day to anyone who would listen.

So he'd get a "year's" worth of experience in less than a month.

He uses that story to make a point:

Mastery takes as long as you want it to take.

The faster your rate of mastery, the shorter the time between you and what you want.

I hope this helps inspires you to realize:

You're closer than you think.

fields.LI Template:
Une dame demande : « Combien vendez-vous vos œufs ?»
Le vieux vendeur répond : « 0.50€ un œuf, madame»
La Dame dit : « Je vais prendre 6 œufs pour 2.50€ ou je pars».
Le vieux vendeur lui répond : « Achetez-les au prix que vous souhaitez, Madame. C'est un bon début pour moi parce que je n'ai pas vendu un seul œuf aujourd'hui et que j’ai besoin de ça pour vivre».

Elle lui a acheté ses œufs à prix marchandé et elle est partie avec la sensation qu'elle avait gagné. Elle est entrée dans sa voiture élégante et est allée dans un restaurant élégant avec son amie.
Elle et son amie ont commandé ce qu'elles voulaient. Elles ont mangé un peu et ont laissé beaucoup de ce qu'elles avaient demandé.

Alors elles ont payés l'addition, qui était de 400€. Les dames ont donné 500€ et ont dit au propriétaire du restaurant chic de garder la monnaie comme pourboire...
Cette histoire pourrait sembler assez normale vis-à-vis du patron du restaurant de luxe, mais très injuste pour le vendeur des œufs...

La question que ça amène est:
Pourquoi avons-nous toujours besoin de montrer que nous avons le pouvoir quand nous achetons à des gens dans le besoin ? Et pourquoi sommes-nous généreux avec ceux qui n'ont même pas besoin de notre générosité ?

Une fois j'ai lu quelque part :
« Mon père avait l'habitude d'acheter des biens à des pauvres à des prix élevés, même s'il n'avait pas besoin de ces choses.

Parfois, il les payait plus cher. J'étais stupéfait. Un jour je lui ai demandé « pourquoi fais-tu ça papa ? »
Alors mon père répondit : « C'est une charité enveloppée dans la dignité, mon fils»

Je sais que la plupart d'entre vous ne partageront pas ce message, mais si vous êtes l'une des personnes qui a pris le temps de lire jusqu'ici...
fields.author: Youssef Koutari

fields.LI Template:
Always be careful with who you share your plans with at work.

A lot of people will be cool with you until they see you start doing better for yourself.

People are Badmind.

Badmind is a Jamaican term we use to describe someone who is jealous or has ill will towards the success of others.

In the workplace this most likely materializes in the form of jealousy when they see you up for a promotion or in the case of this person, up for a new job.

They will do whatever they can to sabotage you and then convince themselves that they are the hero of this story and you the villain.

When I was up for my first promotion my Dad played Bob Marley’s Who the cap fit and made me sing along the following line.

“You don't know who to trust

Your worst enemy could be your best friend

And your best friend your worst enemy”

PS: If you see someone about to move on at your job and your first instinct is to snitch to management on them. You are a horrible person. Just an awful human being.

18 Most-used Linux Commands You Should Know

Linux commands are instructions for interacting with the operating system. They help manage files, directories, system processes, and many other aspects of the system. You need to become familiar with these commands in order to navigate and maintain Linux-based systems efficiently and effectively. The following are some popular Linux commands:

🔹ls - List files and directories
🔹cd - Change the current directory
🔹mkdir - Create a new directory
🔹rm - Remove files or directories
🔹cp - Copy files or directories
🔹mv - Move or rename files or directories
🔹chmod - Change file or directory permissions
🔹grep - Search for a pattern in files
🔹find - Search for files and directories
🔹tar - manipulate tarball archive files
🔹vi - Edit files using text editors
🔹cat - display the content of files
🔹top - Display processes and resource usage
🔹ps - Display processes information
🔹kill - Terminate a process by sending a signal
🔹du - Estimate file space usage
🔹ifconfig - Configure network interfaces
🔹ping - Test network connectivity between hosts

Over to you: What is your favorite Linux command?

👉The "Data Engineering Dictionary: 2024 Edition" (for the Busy Engineer)

🕵️‍♂️Imagine you're a detective looking for clues. Data is like a giant pile of evidence, and these terms are your tools to make sense of it all!

📍Data Mining: Uncovering secrets in data like a detective finds hidden patterns using fancy data mining tools to extract data and connections within data.
📍Data Analytics: Examining data to answer questions and make smart decisions. Think of it like analyzing clues to understand what happened.
📍Data Visualization: Turning complex data into charts and graphs, like a detective's sketch, make it easier to explain what you found.
📍Data Contract: An agreement between data sharers, like a detective making sure they both understand the evidence (data) they're exchanging.
📍Data Modeling: Building a blueprint for your data, like a detective sketching the layout of a crime scene, to organize everything well.
📍Data Integration: Combining data from different places, like integrating together clues from witnesses, to get a complete picture.
📍Data Cleaning: Fixing mistakes in the data, like a detective checking if a witness saw correctly, to make sure your analysis is accurate.
📍Data Warehouse: A central storage for organized data, like a detective's evidence room, where everything is kept safe and accessible for further investigation.
📍Data Mart: A smaller, focused data storage for a specific department, like a detective focusing on fingerprints for a case.
📍Data Lake: A big storage for any kind of data, like a detective's messy desk with notes, photos, and videos, all waiting to be reviewed.
📍Delta Lake: A more reliable data lake, like a detective keeping track of changes to evidence with timestamps, ensuring nothing gets lost.
📍Data Pipeline: A moving assembly line for data, transforming it from one format to another, like sending evidence to a lab for analysis.
📍Data Mesh: Spreading data ownership across teams, like detectives specializing in fingerprints or ballistics, each responsible for their area.
📍Data Lake House: A blend of data lake and warehouse, like a detective's workspace with both organized files and a big box of miscellaneous evidence.
📍Data Swamp: A messy data graveyard, like a pile of unorganized evidence, where it's impossible to find anything useful.
📍Data Fabric: A unified view of all data sources, like a detective board with connections between all the clues, making it easy to see the bigger picture.
📍Data Observability: Monitoring the health and quality of your data systems, like a detective constantly watching for new leads or changes in the case.
📍Data Quality: Ensuring data is accurate, complete, and reliable to verify the authenticity and credibility of evidences.

Mastering these concepts and focusing on each terminology can help professionals provide business-critical data infrastructure and power up the applications!

♐️Image Credits: The Ravit Show (Ravit Jain)

#data #engineering

fields.LI Template:
How many of you have experienced a "bittersweet exit"?

[Sarah] exhaled deeply as she stared at the email announcing the acquisition.

After three grueling years as CRO, they'd finally attained a $100 million exit.

Her mind raced back to countless late nights, missed family dinners, and the constant stress of keeping the company afloat.

She'd poured her heart and soul into this venture, believing her 1% equity stake would be her ticket to financial freedom.

With trembling hands, she opened her equity spreadsheet.

The numbers stared back at her:

1% equity
$100 million exit
$1 million gross payout

Sarah's heart sank.

Two million sounded like a lot, but reality quickly set in.

First came taxes.

At a 37% federal rate plus 13.3% for California, nearly half vanished instantly.

Then there was the liquidation preference for investors, eating another chunk.

Her vesting schedule meant she'd only receive 75% of her shares.

After all deductions, her take-home amount was just over $350,000.

She leaned back, a mix of emotions washing over her. It was a windfall, no doubt. But far from the multi-million dollar life-changing sum she'd imagined.

The fancy sports car and beachfront property she'd dreamed of owning suddenly seemed out of reach.

This payout would cover her kids' college funds and maybe a down payment on a modest home.

It was a significant step forward, but not the leap into wealth she'd envisioned.

As congratulatory messages poured in, Sarah forced a smile. She was grateful, yet couldn't shake a tinge of disappointment. The startup lottery hadn't quite delivered the jackpot she'd hoped for.

She closed her laptop, heading home to share the bittersweet news with her family. Tomorrow, she'd start planning her next move, wiser about the realities of startup economics and the true value of equity.

The point of this story is to temper unrealistic expectations and highlight the need for a more nuanced understanding of equity compensation.

It's not about belittling a substantial payout, but rather about exposing the gap between common perceptions and the economic realities of startup exits for most employees, even at the executive level.

Startup success doesn't guarantee instant millionaire status for most employees.

fields.LI Template:
How does SSH work?
.
.
SSH (Secure Shell) is a network protocol used to securely connect to remote machines over an unsecured network. It encrypts the connection and provides various mechanisms for authentication and data transfer.

SSH has two versions: SSH-1 and SSH-2. SSH-2 was standardized by the IETF.
It has three main layers: Transport Layer, Authentication Layer, and Connection Layer.
1. Transport Layer
The Transport Layer provides encryption, integrity, and data protection to ensure secure communication between the client and server.

2. Authentication Layer
The Authentication Layer verifies the identity of the client to ensure that only authorized users can access the server.

3. Connection Layer
The Connection Layer multiplexes the encrypted and authenticated communication into multiple logical channels.

fields.LI Template:
This concept is the key to achieving all of your goals...

The Law of Reversed Effort:

The law was coined by author Aldous Huxley:

"The harder we try with the conscious will to do something, the less we shall succeed."

It's easy to find examples from your own life where this concept rings true:

When you press to try to complete a creative task, you become less creative.

When you actively push to try to find the perfect partner, you rarely find that person.

When you try to force yourself to fall asleep, you stare at the ceiling awake.

Elite sprinters follow something called the 85% rule:

They try to run at 85% intensity because it keeps them loose, fluid, and effortless.

When they try to run at 100% intensity, their body tenses up and they slow down.

In a Zen parable that I love, a martial arts student approaches his teacher and asks, "How long will it take me to master this craft?"

The teacher replies, "10 years."

The student, looking impatient, responds, "I want to master it faster than that. I will work harder than anyone else. I will push myself to practice for many hours every single day. I won't rest until I become a master. How long will it take then?"

The teacher considers this new information, smiles, and answers, "20 years."

The lesson here is simple: When you adopt a mindset of balanced effort, you achieve greater heights.

Life is not about pushing to the max at all times—this is a recipe for burnout and bad results.

Balance your effort, learn to breathe and flow in everything you do.

If you find that headspace, you will always thrive.

It was August 2019 and I was torn:

I had just qualified for my 3rd President's Club in a row as a director.

The only one to hit every single year in the western US/Canada.

Grew my sales org from 85 to 110+ employees.

Nice house, cars, time-piece collection, etc.

Invites to travel around on the corporate jet.

Great income, great stock portfolio.

I felt fortunate.

It was a good life.

A REALLY good life that most can only dream of...

BUT, I wasn’t happy.

"Was this it?" - I asked myself.

"Can I really do this for the rest of my life?"

More importantly, "DO I want to do it for the rest of my life?"

I realized... I didn't.

I realized, what I really wanted was Time & Freedom.

Freedom to do what I want, when I want, with who I want.

The following month I turned my side hustle into a main hustle.

I went all in and left a 14-year career behind.

Was it scary AF?

Absolutely.

Have I thought about giving up and just getting a job as a CRO or VP somewhere?

Thousands of times.

Fast forward almost 5 years...

600+ clients, insane track record of results, small but mighty team of 5, and a WSJ best-selling book later...

I'm super grateful I made the decision and committed to it.

Three core lessons here:

1) Get crystal clear about what you want in life. And then, do whatever you can to achieve it.

2) If you never bet on yourself, you'll never know what you're capable of becoming and achieving.

3) Sometimes you must be willing to sacrifice the GOOD to ultimately go after the GREAT.

I hope this inspires you this Thursday❤️

fields.LI Template:
Salesforce now requires 3x pipeline coverage instead of 2x.

A lot of companies are sleeping on what this means.

Industry average quota attainment is down below 40%.

Many SaaS companies are choosing to reduce quota.

They acknowledge that firing and hiring salespeople doesn't equal growth.

They realize cycling in new sales leaders doesn't change much.

It actually slows growth and costs a lot of time and money.

They realize how costly it is having a miserable sales team.

Which leads to the notion that the sales team needs to be replaced.

But what if there's another way?

There is and that's what Salesforce is doing.

Instead of lowering quota, they're increasing pipeline coverage from 2x to 3x.

They accepted that:

-deal cycles are now longer
-deal sizes are now smaller
-win rates are now lower

Instead of reducing expectations for the salespeople they're aiming for providing more pipeline to adapt to the change in deal cycles, sizes, and win rates.

They're also adding more enablement, training, and AI resources.

This means even the largest of SaaS companies are accepting that former trends and cookie-cutter growth projections no longer apply.

Many companies will remain in denial about these changes.

But those who plan to survive long-term are accepting reality.

If you can afford to increase pipeline coverage, do it.

Otherwise a reduction in quota might be the wisest investment you make.

The only alternative is spending a fortune to hire more salespeople and hoping for different results.

There's only one guarantee with that play, it'll cost more time and money.

Most companies should just lower quota.

But if you can spend more to create more pipeline, this is a viable option.

Whatever you do, good luck.

fields.LI Template:
Sales advice that makes me cringe:

“If a prospect says your price is too high, say this:”

“Yeah, our process is a lot more thorough. We actually pull out all the guesswork by doing everything for you. I don’t want to have to get on a call and walk through this with you. What I’d rather do is have everything prepared for you, get on this call, and blow your mind with all the information, keeping you from doing a single thing. That’s why people pay us the big bucks in the first place.”

If you’re convincing, you’re losing.

When you convince, you’re subconsciously saying, “I’m right and you’re wrong.”

Nobody wants to be told their wrong.

The way out?

Shift from convincing to understanding.

Here are a few options:

“Sounds like you’re comparing this to what you have or something else you’ve seen.”

“Seems like there’s a ceiling to what you want to invest.”

You’re taking an educated guess about the reason why the prospect thinks your price is too high. It’s called labeling (Chris Voss).

If you guess wrong, that’s okay. People will correct you. Why? People like correcting, but they don’t like being corrected.

When people feel understood you build trust.

And trust is why people choose you.

No trust, no transaction.

fields.LI Template:
Someone venmo'ed me gas money to go see my dad when he was dying.



Last year I was laid off the same week my dad was rushed to the hospital.  He would recover, only to be diagnosed months later, the first day of my new job, with Glioblastoma, passing away in October of 2023.

Every day when my dad was in the hospital, I would make the 1.5-hour trek each way to be with him. He needed us and I promised my mom when she was dying  that I would always look after him.

I posted my story on LinkedIn about looking for a job, my skills and experiences and the human element of balancing being a caretaker for my dad, caring for my kids and husband, and being a full-time jobseeker.

As I posted every day, I grew a community. A community of people who sent me snacks, and cookies, and wine, and inspirational presents and messages every day.

People who wanted to Venmo me money (I declined) and so many STRANGERS who offered to make introductions, referrals, and many who even got me job interviews.

There was one person, a fairly well-known person on LinkedIn, who insisted that I allow him to Venmo me money to pay for gas to go see my dad (I resisted at first).

He asked to remain anonymous, and I respected that. But I still watch as he helps others selflessly to this day

and SO many people anonymously helped me as well.

I've been fortunate to help many people find new jobs, I have helped re-do resumes and profiles, and I have supported Starbucks gift cards and GoFundMe's when I can.

And while I have a wonderful support system, a great family and devoted friends, it was strangers that gave me the daily dose of hope

Hope.. something so absent when you're laid off.

We all can give that gift to someone else.

Be a good human.

#opentowork #layoffs #beagoodhuman #jobseekers #kindnessmatters

fields.LI Template:
Well... I never thought I would do this, but I just blocked Yann LeCun. Yann is one of the most brilliant AI minds out there, often considered one of the "grandfathers" of AI. His work with convolutional neural networks has revolutionized numerous computer and video applications. If you haven't read it, I highly recommend his deep-learning Nature paper with Yoshua Bengio and #GeoffreyHinton titled 'Deep Learning'.

Now, let me explain why I blocked him. Yann and Elon Musk have been publicly sparring on Twitter. While their bickering might seem trivial, it’s disheartening to see such brilliant minds wasting their intellect on petty disputes instead of advancing rockets and AI. However, a particular comment from Yann struck a personal chord with me. Him suggesting that Ketamine damages the brain.

I usually don’t discuss this publicly because it remains somewhat taboo, but I know people whose lives have been profoundly transformed by ketamine treatments. This emerging area of research holds incredible potential to revolutionize how we treat depression and anxiety. For any veterans reading this, we’ve long struggled to find effective treatments for severe PTSD. Many veterans battling PTSD face suicidal ideation, substance abuse, and relationship difficulties. Remarkably, MDMA has been shown to cure PTSD PERMANENTLY after approximately three sessions with a therapist. My sister, in fact, is featured as a therapist in the Netflix MDMA episode of "How to Change Your Mind," link in comments, and I encourage everyone to watch it.

These therapies are not reaching those in need quickly enough. Public opinions like Yann's, which dismiss these treatments, are naive and actively hinder the progress of powerful solutions that can help countless individuals. If Yann reads this, I hope he takes the time to educate himself further on these therapies. Ketamine treatments, for instance, might help him approach criticism with a calmer, more open-minded perspective. He might level up to a future wiser version of himself. He might even have a new, brilliant idea, that leads to a new AI breakthrough for all us.

The future of plant medicine is bright, and we must advocate for it. I do not think it is an exaggeration that lives will be lost unnecessarily this year around the world because individuals lacked access to these life changing treatments. Also, perhaps someone who was on the fence and then decided against these treatments after reading posts like his will suffer longer unnecessarily.
#MentalHealth #PlantMedicine #AI #Innovation #PTSD #Depression #Anxiety #MDMA #KetamineTherapy

88% of people believe a strong company culture is key to business success.

And I’m one of them.

Most job vacancies mention these as work perks:

↳ Fair salary
↳ Paid vacation
↳ Remote work options
↳ Flexible working hours
↳ Team building activities
↳ Quality work equipment
↳ Office tea, coffee, and snacks
↳ A non-toxic work environment
↳ Professional growth opportunities

But these are just the basics a company should provide so employees can do their jobs.

To achieve better outcomes,
companies and leaders must offer better benefits:

➟ Mentorship and guidance.
➟ Resources to prevent burnout.
➟ Support for physical and mental health.
➟ Team-building through activities and training.
➟ Training not just to deepen expertise but to explore new skills.
➟ Salary that reflects employee contributions, not just market rates.

The more a company invests in its employees,
the more productivity and loyalty it receives in return.
